steps.title: Use a manual pipe bender or a hydraulic bender if you have one.
steps.content: Use a manual pipe bender or a hydraulic bender if you have one. You can bend 1 1/4" aluminum conduit by hand, but a manual pipe bender will make it easier. It doesn't matter what you use to bend the pipe, the main thing is how you keep it from collapsing. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Fill the pipe with sand or other material, and secure three layers of window screening, with double hose clamps on the ends.
steps.content: Fill the pipe with sand or other material, and secure three layers of window screening, with double hose clamps on the ends. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Bend the pipe slowly so that you can watch to make sure it bends evenly and doesn't collapse or deform, and watch for cracks that may occur if the pipe is bent too sharply.
steps.content: Bend the pipe slowly so that you can watch to make sure it bends evenly and doesn't collapse or deform, and watch for cracks that may occur if the pipe is bent too sharply. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Use whatever means you have to bend the pipe.
steps.content: Use whatever means you have to bend the pipe. The pipe will not collapse, but remember that there is a radius to wall thickness / diameter formula that must be observed. A loose rule of thumb is a maximum 3 1/2" radius to 1" diameter ratio.

steps.title: Consider building dies to bend your pipe if you have the equipment, you can machine your own bending dies for bending the pipe, or you can rent a manual or hydraulic bender for this purpose.
steps.content: Consider building dies to bend your pipe if you have the equipment, you can machine your own bending dies for bending the pipe, or you can rent a manual or hydraulic bender for this purpose. [4] X Research source
